awd_titl_txt: Prevalence and Functional Significance of Regulated Alternative Splicing in Plant Pathogenic Fungi
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the molecular basis of microbial pathogenicity is vital for deciphering the biological process of disease, and for designing new and effective disease control methods. In spite of advances in treatment of microbial diseases, fungal diseases continue to pose an increasing threat to humans, animals, and plants that often endanger food security and human well-being. The last few decades, in particular, have seen an unprecedented increase in emerging infectious fungal diseases, while the continuous loss to microbial drug resistance of available chemistries for disease control, intensifies the problem and necessitates the development of novel therapeutic strategies. Key to this process is the elucidation of the molecular mechanisms employed by microbes to infect their hosts. In this respect, alternative splicing (AS), a key element in eukaryotic gene expression by which different protein variants are generated from the same gene, is an unexplored feature of microbial pathogenicity which could promote microbial virulence by regulating the optimal production of virulence factors during infection. Thus, the project will focus on a systematic analysis of AS in plant pathogenic fungi, with an emphasis on deciphering its functional significance for parasitic infections. The findings will significantly advance our understanding of fungal pathogenesis and could be used for the development of novel therapeutic treatments for plant diseases through the pharmaceutical manipulation of fungal AS during infection of the host. The project will also be used as a basis for raising public awareness on infectious fungal diseases and training of a diverse student body in molecular plant sciences. 

Most studies on fungal pathogenesis on plants have focused on the discovery and biochemical characterization of virulence factors that contribute to infections and disease, but much less attention has been placed on the epigenetic mechanisms that control transcriptome diversity of virulence-associated genes. AS splicing is perhaps the most crucial posttranscriptional regulatory mechanism of gene expression but, despite its importance in generating proteome diversity and functional complexity in eukaryotic cells, its prevalence, biological role, and functional consequence for fungal pathogenicity have been barely studied. The goal in this project is to systematically identify and characterize AS events in plant pathogenic fungi during a complete infection cycle of their host, in order to provide critical answers to fundamental questions regarding its pervasiveness, species conservation, and contribution to microbial virulence. This area of study is important because regulated AS of virulence-associated genes is a relatively unexplored feature of microbial pathogenicity, which potentially enables microbes to quickly modulate and fine-tune interactions with their host. To achieve its goals, the project will integrate genome-wide transcriptome profiling, with selective detection of novel splice isoforms through targeted proteomics approaches, and functional analyses of candidate AS genes by RNAi-mediated isoform-specific gene targeting. To assess the generality of the findings, the analysis will be done in two phylogenetically related plant pathogenic fungi when infecting their common host. The successful completion of this project could trigger a paradigm-shift in the field of host-microbe interactions by highlighting the importance of AS-mediated post-transcriptional regulation in parasite fitness and virulence.

por.por_cntn:
Fungi are the most potent group of pathogens on plants, responsible for 10-23% of crop loses on a global scale each year. Fungi are also increasingly recognized as important pathogens of humans, and wild and domesticated animals. The last few decades, in particular, have seen an alarming increase in fungal diseases, while the continuous loss to microbial drug resistance of available synthetic chemistries for disease control further intensifies the problem and necessitates the development of novel strategies for treating fungal diseases. Part of the evolutionary success of fungi as pathogens is based on their ability to rapidly respond to their environment and to overcome the immune system of their hosts. However, the pathways of these responses and many aspects of fungal pathogenesis on plants still remain largely unknown.

This project aimed on advancing our understanding of fungal pathogenesis on plants by elucidating the importance to fungal infections on plants of alternative intron splicing (AS) in fungal genes. AS is a key feature of eukaryotic gene expression that increases the diversity of proteins that are produced by genes. Although AS was initially perceived mostly as noise that arises from errors in the cellular intron splicing machinery, it is now recognized as a fundamental component of eukaryotic gene expression and a key strategy for adaptation to stressful conditions. In humans, for instance, it is estimated that nearly 95% of the genes undergo AS when expressed, thereby creating an arsenal of proteins with diverse functions. However, while the biological role and functional consequences of AS have been well studied in humans, very little is known about the contribution of this mechanism to fungal infections on plants.  

In this project we made a systematic analysis of the frequency, type, and conservation of AS events occurring in a plant pathogenic fungus, during a complete infection cycle on its plant host. We also empirically determined the extent to which AS actually contributes to proteome diversity in fungi and attempted to assess its functional significance for fungal infections on plants. Finally, as part of our studies we sequenced the genomes and produced chromosome-level assemblies for five fungal isolates. Overall, these studies are important because AS, particularly in virulence-associated genes, is a largely unexplored feature of microbial pathogenicity but one that potentially provides microbes the means to fine-tune interactions with the host, and one that could be exploited for the development of novel disease treatments.

For our studies we used the Cladosporium fulvum - tomato pathosystem and monitored the dynamics of AS events occurring in this fungus when is infecting its tomato host. Although Clasosporium fulvum is a pathogen of regional only importance, it is one of the earliest fungi used to study molecular plant-microbe interactions. Our studies showed that between 7-11% of the genes in C. fulvum show strong evidence of AS during infections of the tomato host. They also showed that AS was not impacted by the location of the genes on chromosomes and that AS genes were not particularly enriched for specific functions. In contrary to initial expectations, our proteomic studies failed to provide support that AS increased the diversity of proteins that were produced by the fungus during infections, thus questing its contribution to disease. However, this conclusion should be taken with care given the current technical limitations using proteomics technologizes in identifying fungal proteins in complex infected plant tissue. Finally, our studies have shown that chromosomal rearrangements in the genomes of the studied fungal isolates have contributed to their adaptation on the tomato host.   

Apart from advancing our understanding of microbial pathogenesis of plants, the project further provided ample opportunities for training and professional development, to a diverse body of post-doctoral fellows and students that included graduate students, undergraduate students, and high-school internship trainees. Students and post-dos received training in molecular sciences, microbiology, plant pathology and/or bioinformatics. Many of the participants in this project, were also given the opportunity to present their work in national and international conferences and meetings, and publish their research in reputable international peer-reviewed journals. For most students and post-docs, the training and experiences that they have acquired through their participation in this project has been transformative to their nascent careers. The project also generated a wealth of resources that were made available to public data repositories such as NCBI and GitHub, and which can further be exploited by the scientific community to answer additional questions in host-microbe interactions. These include but are not limited to chromosome-scale assemblies and comprehensive gene annotations of five fungal (C. fulvum) isolates, deep dual transcriptomic data and proteomic of a host (tomato) – pathogen (C. fulvum) interaction, and an array of scripts for analyzing these data.

We believe that the above collectively portray the positive impact that the project had to the advancement of science and to society.
